qas.question: Where is the English word God derived from?
Where the first Germanic words for God masculine or feminine?
When did the Germanic words for God take on a masculine form?
What was practiced by the Germanic people before their Christianization?
What did the gaelic root of the word for God mean?
Where does the word God come from originally?
What language does the English word God come from?
What gender where the original Germanic words meaning God in?
Where does the earliest masculine form of the English word for God come from?
Where is the Codex form of the word from?
What was the Argenteus usage based on?
How were the English words for to call originally applied?

context: The earliest written form of the <a6_0>German<a6_0/>ic word God (always, in this usage, capitalized) comes from <b8_0>the 6th-century Christian <a5_0>Codex Argenteus<b8_0/><a5_0/>. The English word itself is derived from <a0_0><b9_0>the Proto-Germanic * ǥuđan<b9_0/><a0_0/>. The reconstructed Proto-Indo-European form * ǵhu-tó-m was likely based <b10_0>on the root * ǵhau(ə)-<b10_0/>, which meant either <a4_0><b11_0>"to call" or "to invoke"<b11_0/><a4_0/>. The Germanic words for God were <b12_0>originally <a1_0><a7_0>neuter<a7_0/>—applying to both genders<b12_0/><a1_0/>—but during the process of the <a2_0>Christianization of the Germanic peoples<a2_0/> from their indigenous <a3_0>Germanic paganism<a3_0/>, the words became a masculine syntactic form.
